person_031.name: JohnMilton
person_031.description: Milton was a poet and polemicist. He wrote the epic poem Paradise Lost.

person_064.name: William III
person_064.description: Stadholder of the United Provinces, 1672-1688 who married Mary, daughter of the English king, James II. Following a plot to overthrow James, William invaded England in 1688 and ultimately secured the English, Scottish and Irish thrones - the 'Glorious Revolution'.

person_065.name: HoratioNelson
person_065.description: Perhaps the most famous naval officer of the day, commanding the victorious Royal Navy fleets in battles such as the Nile, Copenhagen and Trafalgar where he was killed in action.

person_003.name: WilliamAllen
person_003.description: Allen was a Quaker who worked in the pharmaceutical industry. Davy asked him to give lectures on natural philosophy at the RI. FRSL.

person_074.name: Franz JosefGall
person_074.description: German-born, he later worked in Paris on phrenology.

place_007.name: Limerick
place_007.description: Limerick is a city in Ireland, set in Munster province in the south of the country.

place_008.name: Rathkeale
place_008.description: Rathkeale is a town in west County Limerick, in Ireland.

place_009.name: Adare
place_009.description: Adare is a village in County Limerick, Ireland, located south-west of the city of Limerick.

place_142.name: River Shannon
place_142.description: A major river in the island of Ireland, and the longest river in the British Isles.

place_825.name: River Thames
place_825.description: The River Thames, known alternatively in parts as the River Isis, is a river that flows through southern England including London.

place_914.name: River Severn
place_914.description: At 220 miles long, the longest river in Great Britain.

place_071.name: London
place_071.description: The capital city of England and the United Kingdom.

place_106.name: Lakes of Killarney
place_106.description: Three lakes (Lough Leane, Muckross Lake - also called Middle Lake, and Upper Lake) surrounded by the MacGillycuddy's Reeks and now part of Killarney National Park.

place_032.name: Abbeyfeale
place_032.description: Abbeyfeale is a market town in County Limerick, Ireland.

place_1199.name: Kerry
place_1199.description: County in the peninsular southwest of Ireland.

place_102.name: Ross Island
place_102.description: Probably Ross Island, Killarney, Ireland, a claw-shaped peninsular in Killarney. Ross Castle is located here.

place_144.name: Keeper Hill
place_144.description: One of the Silvermine Mountains of County Tipperary, Ireland.

place_036.name: Kildare
place_036.description: Kildare is a town in County Kildare, Ireland.

place_035.name: Carlow
place_035.description: Carlow is the county town of County Carlow, in the south-east of Ireland.

place_010.name: Nenagh
place_010.description: Nenagh is the county town of County Tipperary in Ireland.

place_399.name: Dublin
place_399.description: The capital city of the Republic of Ireland.

place_121.name: England
place_121.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

place_043.name: Edgeworthstown
place_043.description: Edgeworthstown is a town in County Longford, Ireland. It is named after the Edgeworth family, who lived on an estate there. It was the home of Richard Lovell Edgeworth, Associate at the Medical Pneumatic Institution, and his daughter Anna Beddoes, n√©e Edgeworth.

place_038.name: Athlone
place_038.description: Athlone is a town in central Ireland.

place_039.name: Portumna
place_039.description: Portumna is a market town in the south-east of County Galway, Ireland, on the border with and linked by a bridge to County Tipperary.

place_040.name: Banagher
place_040.description: Banagher is a town in Ireland, located in the midlands, on the western edge of County Offaly in the province of Leinster, on the banks of the River Shannon.

place_042.name: River Inny
place_042.description: The River Inny is a river within the Shannon River Basin in Ireland.

place_041.name: Ballymahon
place_041.description: Ballymahon on the River Inny is a town in the southern part of County Longford, Ireland.

place_1326.name: Westmeath
place_1326.description: a county in Ireland, in the province of Leinster.

place_044.name: Wicklow
place_044.description: County Wicklow is a county in Ireland on the east coast, south of Dublin.

place_046.name: Longford
place_046.description: A county in Ireland, Longford is also the name of the county town.

place_047.name: Donegal
place_047.description: Donegal is a town at the mouth of the River Eske, in north-west Ireland.

place_048.name: Belturbet
place_048.description: Belturbet is a town in County Cavan, Ireland.

place_049.name: Enniskillen
place_049.description: Enniskillen is the largest town in County Fermanagh, Northern Ireland. It is in the middle of the county, between the Upper and Lower sections of Lough Erne.

place_051.name: Lough Erne
place_051.description: Lough Erne is the name of two connected lakes in County Fermanagh, Northern Ireland. It is the second-biggest lake system in Northern Ireland and Ulster, and the fourth biggest in Ireland.

place_052.name: Ballyshannon
place_052.description: Ballyshannon is a town in County Donegal, Ireland.

place_1327.name: Church Hill
place_1327.description: a small village in Enniskillen, Ireland.

place_053.name: Sligo
place_053.description: The town of Sligo, in the north of Ireland, straddles the Garavogue River where it meets Sligo Bay.

place_140.name: Leitrim
place_140.description: A county in the north of Ireland.

place_054.name: Fermanagh
place_054.description: County Fermanagh is one of the thirty-two counties of Ireland, one of the nine counties of Ulster and one of six counties of Northern Ireland.

place_050.name: River Erne
place_050.description: Located in the north-west of the island of Ireland; the second-longest river in Ulster.

place_057.name: Benbulbin
place_057.description: Benbulben or Ben Bulben, a large flat-topped nunatak rock formation in County Sligo. Davy refers to the formation as 'benvallin'.

place_1328.name: River Eske
place_1328.description: The River Eske is a river in County Donegal, Ireland. It begins at Lough Eske in the southeast of the county before flowing mainly westwards to the town of Donegal and into the Atlantic Ocean via Donegal Bay. Donegal Town is the only major settlement through which it flows. Although Davy omits the final "e" it is clear from context he means this river, rather than the English or Scottish rivers spelt "Esk".

place_059.name: Ramelton
place_059.description: Also known as Rathmelton. A town and townland in County Donegal, Ireland.

place_060.name: Cavan
place_060.description: County Cavan is a county in Ireland. It is in the province of Ulster and is part of the Northern and Western Region.

place_1329.name: Ballinagh
place_1329.description: It is possible that Davy is referring to Ballinagh (also known as Bellananagh) in County Cavan, Ireland

place_061.name: Ballybofey
place_061.description: Ballybofey is a town located on the south bank of the River Finn, County Donegal, Ireland.

place_062.name: River Finn
place_062.description: The River Finn is a river in the west of Ulster, the northern province in Ireland. The river mainly flows through County Donegal.

place_063.name: Letterkenny
place_063.description: Letterkenny is a large town in County Donegal, Ireland, on the River Swilly in the north-west of Ulster.

place_064.name: Arakil
place_064.description: Arokil is the Errigal mountain of the same range; the handwriting on page 69 in notebook 15B was reproduced by John Davy along with the poem 'Mucrish and Arokil, ye pair...' in Tait's Edinburgh Magazine for 1836, vol. iii, p. 252. See also Memoirs, vol. 1, pp. 287 ff.

place_070.name: Mucrish
place_070.description: Muckish, one of the Derryveagh Mountains. See the poem 'Mucrish and Arokil, ye pair...' in Tait's Edinburgh Magazine for 1836, vol. iii, p. 252. See also Memoirs, vol. 1, pp. 287 ff.

place_065.name: Swilly
place_065.description: Lough Swilly, a glacial fjord or sea inlet, in County Donegal, Ireland.

place_243.name: Carrara
place_243.description: Carrara is a city in central Italy.

place_067.name: Loch Fern
place_067.description: Loch Fern, or Lough Fern, a lake in County Donegal, Ireland.

place_068.name: Loch Salt
place_068.description: Loch Salt, Lough Salt, a lake in County Donegal, Ireland.

place_069.name: Kilmacrennan
place_069.description: Also known as Kilmacrennan, a village, town and civil parish in County Donegal, Ireland.

place_072.name: Limavady
place_072.description: A market town in County Londonderry, Ireland.

place_073.name: Raphoe
place_073.description: A market town in County Donegal, Ireland.

place_074.name: Derry
place_074.description: Also known as Londonderry, a city on the River Foyle in Northern Ireland.

place_075.name: River Foyle
place_075.description: The River Foyle is a river in west Ulster in the north-west of the island of Ireland, which flows from the confluence of the Rivers Finn and Mourne at the towns of Lifford in County Donegal and Strabane in County Tyrone.

place_076.name: Magilligan
place_076.description: A peninsula in north-west County Londonderry in Northern Ireland.

place_077.name: Belfast
place_077.description: Belfast is the capital city of Northern Ireland.

place_1330.name: Lough Foyle
place_1330.description: Lough Foyle, sometimes Loch Foyle, is the estuary of the River Foyle, on the north coast of Ireland.

place_066.name: Mucruss
place_066.description: Now Mount Muckish, in County Donegal, Ireland.

place_1081.name: Binevenagh
place_1081.description: Possibly Davy is mispelling Binevenagh here, a Basaltic mountain in County Derry, Northern Ireland, which was used to by French geologist Nicolas Desmarest in the debate between Neptunists and the Plutonists.

place_146.name: Portrush
place_146.description: A small seaside town on north coast of County Antrim, Northern Ireland.

place_480.name: Coleraine
place_480.description: Coleraine is a town in County Derry, Northern Ireland.

place_093.name: Skerries
place_093.description: The Skerries are a group of islands off the Antrim coast of Northern Ireland, near Portrush.

place_126.name: Giant's Causeway
place_126.description: The Giant's Causeway is an extensive area of columnar basalt in County Antrim, Northern Ireland, formed by an ancient volcanic fissure eruption.
